Name: di fu zi
地膚子
Other name: sao zhou zai (Taiwan) 掃帚栽(台灣)

Maladies Treated: Internal use: inflammations and infections of the urinary bladder, prostate, kidneys, inflammations and the urinary tract
Internal use: gonorrhea, edema, beriberi, difficulty in urination
External applications: itchy and damp testicle area, boils, ringworms
External application (water decoction of leaves): erysipelas (丹毒), used for improving night vision
External application: skin ulcers, scabies, eczema, itchy rash
External application (washing eyes): relieves pain and discomfort in the eyes due to 'sparrow blindness' (雀盲澀痛)
Medical Function: Inhibits fungi: the water extract inhibits Achorion Schonleinii, M. Ferruginum, and other fungi that regularly cause skin diseases. The extract shows different degrees of inhibition on these pathogenic skin fungi including Achorion Schonleinii (許蘭氏黃癬菌), Microsporum ferrugineum (鐵銹色小芽胞癬菌), and Nocardia (星形奴卡氏菌).
Effect on immune system: inhibits phagocytosis of monocytes and inhibits Delayed Type Hypersensitivity (DTH). Its DTH effect can be related to its function of inhibiting phagocytosis of monocytes.
Yijing qiang yin: benefits the essence and strengthens the yin
Removes deficiency heat
Promotes urination and relieves stranguria ('open stranguria')
Dosage: Internal use: 3–15 g in decoction. External use: appropriate amount, boil with water and wash affected area.
Samples of Formulae:
Di fu zi tang (地膚子湯) for erysipelas (St. Anthony's fire): Di fu zi (Kochia fruit) 30 g, Jin yin hua (Honeysuckle flower) 30 g, Ju hua (Chrysanthemum flower) 30 g, Jing jie (Schizonepeta stem) 15 g, Fang feng (Siler root) 15 g. Make into a decoction. Use as tea. (《陝甘寧青中草藥選》)

Wet and itchy groin: Di fu zi (Kochia fruit), She chuang zi (Cnidium fruit), Ku shen (Sophora root), Hua jiao (Sichuan pepper), equal amounts of each. Boil with water and wash the affected area. (《湖北中草藥志》)

For eczema, itchy rash: Di fu zi (Kochia fruit) 15 g, Bai xian pi (Dictamnus root bark) 9 g, Chuan bi bo (Ardisia crispa) 12 g, Ku shen (Sophora root) 9 g, Ye ju hua (Wild chrysanthemum flower) 9 g, Sheng di huang (Raw Rehmannia root) 12 g, Chi shao yao (Red peony root) 9 g, Dang gui (Chinese Angelica root) 9 g. Make into a decoction with water. Drink as tea. (《中藥臨床應用》除濕消疹湯)
Contraindications: Not to use if it is not a damp heat condition (非濕熱症忌用).
Notes:
Seeds of these herbs are being used as fake substitutes: li (Chenopodium album L.), gang song (Baeckea frutescens L.), tian xian zi (Hyoscyamus niger L.).

地膚子之偽品: 崗松 (Baeckea frutescens L.), 藜 (Chenopodium album L.), 天仙子 (Hyoscyamus niger L.).

Geography: Now in northern part of China
Maladies Treated: Acute inflammation of the mammary gland (acute mastitis, early stage) (seed)
Lack of milk (seed)
Neuralgia of the rib cage
Herpes zoster (shingles)
Cuts and open wounds
To extract thorns and splinters
Promote flow of menses (promote menstruation)
Promote urination
Boils
Pain caused by overabundance of mother's milk (pain and swelling due to excessive milk)
Lack of milk or milk not flowing (used as lactagogue)
Amenorrhea
Medical Function: Anti-tumor
Anti-early pregnancy
Increases the cAMP of plasma and also the tissue of the uterus
Potential to prevent fertilization
Using the seed of wang bu liu xing, with the pressure point of the ear, can constrict the gall bladder
Sub-clinically is used for expelling stones in the gall bladder. By applying the pressure point of the ear, the gall bladder excretes bile and also expels the smallest stones into the intestine
Samples of Formulae:
For early stage acute mastitis: 'stuffing nose method': Use wang bu liu xing (王不留行) 15 pieces, raw ban xia (半夏, Pinellia ternata tuber) 1/2 piece, bai jie zi (白芥子, white mustard seed) 5 pieces, raw ginger. Smash in 2 layers of gauze and make into an oblong shape. Insert into the opposite nostril of where the tumor is. Once a day, 2–3 hours each time. Generally in 1 day the symptoms are relieved. In 3–5 days, can be healed. If pus is formed, it has to be drained and do not use this therapy.

For lack of milk or milk not flowing:
Formula 1: wang bu liu xing (王不留行) 8 g, chuan shan jia (穿山甲, baked, pangolin scale) 8 g, ju mai (瞿麦, dianthus) 8 g, mai dong (麦冬, ophiopogon root) 8 g. Add 600 cc water. Simmer down to 200 cc. Make into 3 servings, taken with yellow rice wine 3 times a day.
Formula 2: lean pork 150 g, wang bu liu xing (王不留行) 12 g, huang qi (黄耆, astragalus root) 22 g. Make into soup.

For treatment of herpes zoster (shingles):
Formula 1: wang bu liu xing (王不留行) 30 g, eggs 1 or 2. Use low heat to bake wang bu liu xing into yellow-brownish color (not char). Grind into powder. Pour out the egg white and mix with the herbs. Make into a paste and apply to the affected area 3 times a day.
Formula 2: wang bu liu xing (王不留行) 12 g. Using low heat, stir fry until 'popped'. Mix with sesame oil and make into a paste. Apply to the affected area 2–3 times a day. If the blister is already broken, the herbs can be sprinkled directly onto the area. Results: 13 patients. Usually after 10–20 minutes, the pain obviously goes down. In 1–2 days, scabs are formed. In 3–5 days, the scabs fall off and skin heals. No side effects.
Contraindications: Use care in cases of pregnancy. Not to be used for mastitis with abscess formation (when pus is present, it must be drained surgically; do not use the 'stuffing nose method').
Research: wang bu liu xing can inhibit Ehrlich ascites cancer and lung cancer. (王不留行對艾氏腹水瘤，人體肺癌有抑制作用。)
Notes:
For early stage breast cancer: The effective therapy is to remove tumors before it spread, usually before the tumors reach 4 mm, according to a famous oncologist Richard Dorsay M.D. of U.S.A. The above formula is for acute mastitis, not for cancer.

偽品：野牡丹科 (Melastomaceae) 植物 野牡丹 Melastoma candidum 的根。 (Counterfeit products include roots of Melastoma candidum [family Melastomaceae].)

Name: li lu
藜蘆
Biological: Veratrum schindleri Loesi. f. (天目藜蘆)
Veratrum grandiflorum Loes. f. (毛葉藜蘆)
Veratrum dahuricum (Turcz.) Loes. f. (興安藜蘆)
Hemerocallis thunbergii Baker [麝暑萱 (華東地區也曾用)]
Hemerocallis citrina Baroni[金針菜  (華東地區也曾用)]
Other name: cong bai li lu 蔥白藜蘆
cong guan li lu 蔥管藜蘆

Geography: mainly produced in Shanxi, Hebei, Henan, Shandong, Liaoning provinces of China
Maladies Treated: Scabies (external application: make into fine powder, add vegetable oil, make paste for scabies)
Ringworm (external application: make into fine powder, add vegetable oil, make paste for ringworm)
Lice (external application: make into fine powder, add vegetable oil, make paste for lice)
Promoting vomiting (internal use)

Used with other herbs (fang feng [Ledebouriella root], gua di [melon stalk], li lu [veratrum root and rhizome]) to promote vomiting, especially to induce vomiting of phlegm and saliva as emergency treatment
Medical Function: Lowers blood pressure
Lowers heart rate
Lowers respiration rate
Dosage: In pill or powder form: 0.3 g to 0.9 g. 0.3 克至0.9 克，宜作散劑。External application: use appropriate amount. 外用適量。
Samples of Formulae:
To promote vomiting: Use fang feng (Ledebouriella root), gua di (melon stalk), li lu (veratrum root and rhizome). Grind into fine powder. Take a small amount. Take with warm drinking water to promote vomiting.

如欲湧吐痰涎，作為急救，可用防風 (fang feng, Ledebouriella root)，瓜蒂 (gua di, melon stalk)，藜蘆 (li lu, veratrum root and rhizome) 三味，研細末，取少量，溫水送服以催吐。

Note: Vomiting caused by taking this herb can be stopped by drinking the decoction of the white portion of green onion (蔥湯 white portion of green onion soup). 作催吐用。本品有劇毒，用時宜慎。用量為﹕0.3 克至0.9 克。服本品後吐者服蔥湯即止。
Contraindications:
Do not take li lu in cases of pregnancy or if the body is weak.身體虛弱及孕婦忌用。

Very toxic; do not use long term or in excessive dose.本品有劇毒，不宜久服，多服。

Li lu antagonizes ren shen (ginseng), dan shen (salvia root), sha shen (adenophora root), xuan shen (Scrophularia root), ku shen (sophora root), xi xin (asarum), shao yao (peony root), and is not compatible with da huang (rhubarb) and green onion (蔥白 white portion of green onion).

Toxic reactions include: lowering of blood pressure, lowering of heart rate, slowing of respiration rate. The alkaloids mainly act on the motor, sensory and vagus nerves, and also on the CNS and striated muscles: initially stimulate, then paralyze. Death can result from paralysis of the CNS of the respiratory system and heart. 藜蘆鹼主要作用於運動神經﹐感覺神經及迷走神經，並作用於中樞神經及橫紋肌，使之先興奮後麻痹，可因心臟﹐呼吸中樞麻痹而危及生命。
Research: The main effect of the alkaloids of li lu is on the nerves of motor nerves, sensory nerves, and vagus nerves, as well as the CNS and striated muscles. It initially stimulates, then paralyzes. Death can result due to paralysis of the CNS of the respiratory system and heart.藜蘆鹼主要作用於運動神經﹐感覺神經及迷走神經，並作用於中樞神經及橫紋肌，使之先興奮後麻痹，可因心臟﹐呼吸中樞麻痹而危及生命。
Notes:
Symptoms of toxicity include: sensation of poking by needles in the throat and tongue, burning sensation in the upper abdomen and breast bone, drooling, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, blood in stool, numbness around the mouth area, blurry vision, hazy mind, arrhythmia. In serious cases, blood pressure drops, vertigo, headache, difficulty in breathing, whole body spasm and eventually heart and breathing stop. 一般中毒舌及咽喉有針刺樣感覺，上腹部及胸骨後有燒灼感，還有流涎﹐惡心﹐嘔吐﹐腹痛腹瀉﹐血性大便﹐口周圍麻木﹐視覺模糊﹐神志不清﹐心律失常等。嚴重中毒可引起血壓下降﹐眩暈﹐頭痛﹐呼吸困難﹐全身痙攣，最後可至心跳或呼吸停止。

Antidote: Lavage with potassium permanganate solution or with 1% tannin acid. If diarrhea is not serious, magnesium sulfate can be used to induce diarrhea. 高錳酸鉀液或 1% 鞣酸洗胃。腹瀉不嚴重時，可給硫酸鎂導瀉。

Rhizoma of li lu contains: didesacetyl protoveratrine (雙去乙酰基原藜蘆鹼)

Name: mu tong
guan mu tong
chuan mu tong
huai tong
bai mu tong
Biological: Aristolochia debilis (guan mu tong 關木通)
Clematidis Armandii Franch (chuan mu tong 川木通)
Clematidis Armandii Franch (huai tong 淮通)
Akebia trifoliata Koiz. var. australis Rehd. (bai mu tong 白木通)
Akebia lobata var. Decne. var. clematifolia (Siebold et Zucc.) Ito (synonym)
Akebia trifoliata var. var. clematifolia (Siebold et Zucc.) Nakai (synonym)
Akebia trifoliata var. var. honanensis T. Shimizu (synonym)

Geography: Sichuan, Hubei, Guangxi, Yunnan, Jiangxi, Guizhou, Jiangsu: Caulis Akebiae Trifoliatae (bai mu tong 白木通)
Jilin, Liaoning, Heilongjiang, Shaanxi, Gansu, Shanxi: Caulis Aristolochiae Manshuriensis; Aristolochia debilis (guan mu tong 關木通)
Sichuan, Hunan, Shaanxi, Guizhou, Hubei, Yunnan, Guangdong, Guangxi: Caulis Clematidis Armandii (chuan mu tong 川木通)
Taiwan Province of China and Japan: Akebia longeracemosa Matsum
Maladies Treated: Promotes urination: for treatment of urinary tract infection and urinary difficulty (小便不利, 五淋)
Edema (水腫浮大)
Sore throat (咽喉痛)
Gynecological: amenorrhea (婦女經閉), insufficient lactation (乳汁不通)
Pain in the joints, low grade fever with achiness (身隱熱疼痛拘急), cold feet but with mild fever (足冷伏熱)
Blood deficiency: for blood injury, mu tong is suitable to free the mind orifices (傷血，宜木通以通心竅)
Medical Function: Diuretic effect: Rabbits under strict water intake control were orally administered tincture of mu tong (with evaporated alcohol plus water dilution filter) at 0.5g/kg daily for five days. Result: There was a very significant diuretic effect. The ash of mu tong had no diuretic effect, indicating the diuretic effect is caused by active ingredients other than potassium salt. Administration of mu tong decoction by oral or intravenous feeding produced a diuretic effect.
The saponins of Akebia longeracemosa Matsum (produced in Taiwan Province of China and Japan) also possess diuretic effect on rats and mice.
Antibacterial effect: According to preliminary in vitro studies, either extract by soaking or by decocting, mu tong can inhibit a variety of pathogenic fungi to different degrees.
Anti-inflammatory effect: In rats with experimental arthritis, there was some inhibition.
Hypnotic effect: mu tong can prolong the sleeping time in mice caused by pentobarbital sodium cyclohexyl.
Analgesic effect: mu tong has a certain analgesic effect.

Cardiovascular effects: Low concentration had no obvious effect on the isolated rabbit intestine and atrium; high concentration caused contraction of the intestine and inhibition of the atrium. Isolated rabbit ear vascular contraction observed.
Toxicity: Oral toxicity is very low, but certain toxicity after injection.
Samples of Formulae: long dan xie gan tang (龍膽瀉肝湯, Longdan Xiegan Decoction), ba zhen san (八正散, Bazheng San), ba wei dai xia fang (八味帶下方, Bawei Daixia Formula)
Contraindications:
Do not use on those without internal damp heat, fluid deficient, qi deficient, spermatorrhea, frequent urination, or during pregnancy. 內無濕熱﹐津虧氣弱﹐精滑溲頻者﹐及孕婦忌服。
Guan mu tong (Aristolochiae Manshuriensis or Aristolochia debilis) is toxic to kidneys. 關木通對腎臟有毒。
Today in China, all manufactured formulae that contain guan mu tong (Aristolochia debilis) are banned because of the toxicity to the kidneys.
Research:
In America, the herb mu tong labeled as Akebia contained aristolochic acid when tested, indicating mislabeling and presence of a nephrotoxin.
Today, ninety five percent of mu tong used in China is from the stem of Aristolochia debilis (Aristolochiae Manshuriensis), called guan mu tong 關木通. These plants are usually grown in the northeastern provinces of China, formerly called Manchuria.
According to a report, the herb labeled as 'Akebia' sold in America were all tested containing aristolochic acid which is toxic to the kidneys.
95% of mu tong sold in the market is guan mu tong, which belongs to the Aristolochiaceae family and is toxic to kidneys. All proprietary medicines containing guan mu tong are now banned from sale.
Notes:
The fruit is called ba yue za (八月紮).
